intro: Oplismenus affinis, commonly known as the common sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland and marshy environments. It belongs to the family Cyperaceae, which includes sedges, grasses, and related plants. The plant has triangular stems and narrow, grass-like leaves, typical of many sedges. Its small, three-parted flowers are usually clustered in spikelets, and it produces three-sided, triangular fruits. Oplismenus affinis plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various aquatic and terrestrial organisms.
